Title.evidence: Title: Randomised Controlled Trial of Surgical Ablation for Atrial Fibrillation

Trial_Design.evidence: This randomised controlled trial was conducted in Brazil, enrolling patients with symptomatic AF refractory to antiarrhythmic drugs or catheter ablation.

Participants.evidence: enrolling patients with symptomatic AF refractory to antiarrhythmic drugs or catheter ablation.

Intervention.evidence: Participants were randomised to receive either the Cox-Maze IV procedure with LAA occlusion or standard medical therapy.

Objective.evidence: This study evaluates the efficacy of the Cox-Maze IV procedure and left atrial appendage (LAA) occlusion in patients with AF.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was freedom from AF at 12 months.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was computer-generated, and allocation was concealed.

Blinding.evidence: Blinding was applied to outcome assessors.

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 200 participants were randomised: 100 to the intervention group and 100 to the control group, between January 2020 and June 2021.

Number_Analysed.evidence: In the intervention group, 98 participants were analysed using an intention-to-treat approach, while 97 were analysed in the control group.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The intervention group showed a 92% AF freedom rate at 12 months compared to 0% in the control group (p < 0.001).

Harms.evidence: Adverse events included renal dysfunction and pacemaker requirement in <5% of the intervention group, with no increase in overall mortality.

Funding.evidence: Funding: Supported by Brazilian Ministry of Health.
